utterance: Ding 'em, tell 'em to bring their dogs. Mind now ! tell 'em to bring their dogs.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Go ahead, honey ! Cut just as big a dash as you please with your Thanksgiving. I '11 enjoy it as much as you will, maybe more. The Lord knows we 've got a heap to be thankful for. We '11 cut a big dash and be thankful, and then when Christmas comes we '11 cut a big dash and be happy.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Mr. Rivers I do hope you have n't asked your friends to bring their hound-dogs with them. Why, they '11 take the whole place. You 've got twelve of your own. What on earth do you want with any more ?
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Why, yes, honey, Harvey Dennis and Matt Kilpat rick and Tom Collingsworth will fetch their dogs, and I reckon maybe Jack Casswell and Bill Hearn will fetch theirs.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Mercies upon us! I thought you surely had dogs enough of your own.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Why, honey, you 've let the niggers chunk my dogs till they are no manner account.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Well, I do hate hound-dogs ! sneaking around, sticking their noses in the pots and pans, and squalling like they 're killed if you lift your hand. Why, the foxes come right up in the yard and take off the geese and ducks, where your dogs could see them if they were n't too lazy to open their eyes.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Those are just the foxes we 're going to catch, honey
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Well, I 'd rather feed the foxes a whole year than to have forty or fifty hound-dogs quartered on this place three or four days.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Well, I guess I '11 have bigger trou bles than that before I die. If I don't, it will be a mercy.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: If you don't, honey, you '11 live and die a happy woman
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Just think, folks ! Four more days and I '11 be eighteen ! A woman grown, but with the sweet disposition of a child !
speaker: Mary Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Where did you hear that?
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Why, I heard you say those words to father no longer than last night. Look, fa ther ! mother is actually blushing !
speaker: Mary Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mrs. Rivers

utterance: I believe I did say something like that, I intended to tell your fa ther afterward that very few children have sweet dispositions. But my mind has been worried all day with the thought of the hound-dogs we 've got to feed.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mary Rivers

utterance: Oh, father ! are we to have a fox-hunt ? And may I go ?
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: Now, Mr. Eivers, I think that is going too far. I certainly do. I have always been opposed to it. There is no earthly reason why Mary at her age should get on a horse and go galloping about the country with a crowd of yelling men and howling dogs. It may be well enough for the men, though I think they could be bet ter employed, but I think the line ought to be drawn at the women.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Why, mother, how many times have I been fox-hunting with father ?
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: Just as many times as you have made me miserable just that many times and no more.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Now, momsy ! don't scold your onliest and oldest daughter
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: Don't wheedle around me ! Mr. Rivers, you need n't be winking at Mary be hind your paper. I do think it is a shame that you should allow your daughter to go ripping and tearing about the country hunt ing foxes. I think it is a burning shame. I positively do.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mary Rivers

utterance: Well, honey
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: I don't care what anybody says, Here is Mary old enough to get married, and now she must go scamper ing about with a lot of men on horseback. It is ridiculous !
speaker: Mrs. Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mary Rivers

utterance: You hear that, father ? Momsy says I 'm old enough to get married. I '11 marry the man that brings me the fox's brush the day after Christmas. And momsy shall bake the cake, and she '11 burn it just as the cake is burning now.
speaker: Mary Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mrs. Rivers

utterance: I declare, if old Dilsey has gone to sleep and left that fruit-cake to burn, I '11 send her to the overseer !
speaker: Mrs. Rivers
addressee: Colonel Elmore Rivers and Mary Rivers

utterance: I reckon you know, precious, that we '11 have to catch the fox before your beau can give you the brush. But we '11 have some good dogs here. So you 'd better tell your sweetheart to stir his stumps. Maybe the wrong chap will get the brush.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Why, you won't let me have one little joke, father, Of course I won't marry the man that gives me the brush unless he 's the right person.
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: This mince-pie, was made by Mary. I don't think she put enough of the twang into it.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: It is magnificent !
speaker: Andy Colston

utterance: Superb !
speaker: Jack Preston

utterance: It 's as good as any, but this pie business is mighty de ceiving. Miss Molly is eighteen, and if she can bake a pone of corn-bread as it ought to be baked, she 's ready to get married.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: That is her strong point ! She beats anybody at that.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Well, then, you just go and get her wedding goods.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: I 'm beginning to think so, too, No longer than the other day she declared she 'd marry the man that brings her the fox's brush to-morrow. What do you think of that ?
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Why, father !
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: Then it 's just as good as settled, I 'm just as certain to tail that fox as the sun shines. I rubbed my rabbit-foot on Music and Rowdy before I started, and I '11 whistle 'em up and shake it at 'em to-night.

utterance: But remember, Mr. Collingsworth, you are already married
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: I know I know ! But my old woman has been complaining might'ly of late com plaining might'ly. But something told me that I 'd need the big gray, and, sure enough, here 's right where the big gray comes in.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: I brought my sorrel along

utterance: Oh, you did ? Well, I '11 give your sorrel half-way across a ten-acre field and run right spang over you with my big gray before you can get out of the way. There ain't but one nag I 'm afraid of, and that 's Jack Preston's roan filly. You did n't bring her, did you, Jack ? Well, I '11 give you one tussle anyhow. But that roan is a half-sister of Waters's Timoleon. I declare, Jack, you ought n't to be riding that filly around in the underbrush.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: She needs exercise, She 's been in the stable eating her head off for a week.
speaker: Jack Preston

utterance: Well, just keep her on the ground and I '11 try to follow along after you the best I can.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: How is it, Harvey?

speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: Now, Miss Mary, which of the two would you like to receive the brush from ?
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: I '11 allow you to choose for me. You are a good judge.
speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: Well, if a man was to back me up against the wall, and draw a knife on me, and I could n't help myself, I 'd say Preston. That 's a fact.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: That 's my beauty ! That 's Music, telling what she thinks she knows. Wait !
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: Now she 's telling what she knows
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: If you '11 excuse me, Miss Mary, I '11 go down and try to untangle that skein. That fox is n't forty yards from Music's nose.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: Wait/'

utterance: Whale bone and Music and Rowan have gone off to  investigate matters. Let 's hear what they  have to say.
speaker: Matt Kilpatrick

utterance: Don't ride so hard, Miss Mary,
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: Now/'
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: we '11 ride a  half-mile to the left here, and I think we '11  then be in the hock of the ham.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

speaker: Mary Rivers

utterance: Oh, I was talking to myself/'
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: If you 11 put  a ham on the ground and make an outline of  it, you '11 get a good map of this chase, in my  opinion. The line at the big end of the ham  will be Little River. The line on the right  will be the way the fox went, and the line on  the left will be the way he '11 come back. If  you ask me why a fox will run up stream  when he 's not hard pushed, I '11 never tell  you, but that 's the way they do.
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

utterance: He 's cut out a bigger ham than I  thought he would
speaker: Tom Collingsworth

take 'em farther  away from the house the next time you kill

speaker: Mrs. Rivers

You don't mean to  tell me that you are going to put yourself on  a level with Bill Favers and go trolloping  around the country, hunting negroes with  hound-dogs? I never heard you say that
any of your family ever stooped to such as
that.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: But they never had such a rantankerous nigger to deal with.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Just as he is, just so he was made/'
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: I know that mighty well/'
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: But the time has come when he  ought to be taken in hand. I could get Bill  Favers's dogs and run him down in an hour,  but I 'm going to catch my own nigger with  my own nigger dog.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Why, Mr. Rivers, you have n't a dog on  the place that will run a pig out of the gar den, much less catch a negro. There are ten  or fifteen hound-dogs around the yard, and  they are actually too no-account to scratch  the fleas off.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance: Well,
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Matt Kilpatrick has promised to give  me one of his beagles, and I 'm going to  take him and train him to track niggers.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Another dog on the place !
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

utterance:
Well, you '11 have to sell  some negroes. We can't afford to feed a lot  of no-account negroes and no-account dogs
without selling something. You can't even  give the dogs away and I would n't let you  impose on anybody that way, if you could ;
so you '11 have to sell some of the negroes.
They are lazy and no-account enough, good ness knows, but they can manage to walk  around and pick up chips and get a thimble ful of milk from twenty cows, and sweep off  the porch when there 's anybody to keep  them awake.
speaker: Mrs. Rivers

De wuss

De white folks kin git 'im any time dey

utterance: De Lord knows I 'd quit hidin' out in de woods ef I wuz you. I would n't be gwine 'roun' like some wil' var mint dat I would n't ! I 'd let um come git me an' do what dey gwine ter do. Dey can't kill you.
speaker: Uncle Shade's wife

utterance: Dat 's so.
speaker: Aunt Mirny

utterance: How come you ain't up yonder whar you b'long ?
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: What good dat gwine ter do ?
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: Now, ez ter dat/ I can't tell you. It may do harm, an' it may not, but what good it gwine ter do, I 'm never is ter tell you.
speaker: Aunt Mirny

utterance: What de dog gwine ter do ?
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: You mos' too much fer me. Mos' a long ways too much. Ef you kin git off de groun' an' walk in de elements, de dog ain't gwine do nothin'. Maybe you kin do dat ; I dunno. But ef you can't dat ar dog '11 track you down sho ez you er settin' dar.
speaker: Aunt Mirny

utterance: Well, den, what you gwine ter do ?
speaker: Uncle Shade's wife

utterance: I '11 tell you. Ef he don't ketch me, I ain't comin' back. Ef he ketch me, I '11 show 'im dat, an' ef dat ain't do no good, I 'm gwine ter jump off Injun Bluff in de river.
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: Sho nuff ?
speaker: Uncle Shade's wife

utterance: Sho nuff !
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: Where did Shade sleep last night ?
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Well, suh, what little sleepin' he done, he done right dar, suh right dar in de baid, suh.
speaker: Shade's wife

utterance: What do you mean by defying me in this way ? What do you mean by running away, and hiding in the bushes ? Do you suppose I am going to put up with it ?
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Well, suh, ef my mistiss wuz 'bove groun' dis day I 'd be right whar she wuz at, right dar doin' my work, des like I usen ter. Dat what I mean, suh.
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: Do you mean to tell me, you impudent rascal, that because your mistress is dead you have the privilege of running off and hiding in the woods every time anybody snaps a finger at you ? Why, if your mistress was alive to-day she J d have your hide taken off.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: She never is done it yet, suh, an' I been live wid 'er in about fifty year.
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: Well, I J m going to do it. Take off that coat/

utterance: Well, suh, 'fo' I does dat I got sump'n here I want you to look at.

utterance: I want to see nothing/ I 've put up with your rascality until I 'm tired. Off with that coat !
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: But I got a letter fer you, suh, an' dey tol' me to put it in yo' han' de fus time you flew'd up an' got mad wid me.

We tuck 'n' come'd out hfcre, an' fished, an' I got you a hankcher full er deze here quare rocks, an' you played like dey wuz diamon's, an' you up'd an' said that you liked me better 'n you liked anybody 'ceppin' yo' own blood kin. But times done change, suh. I 'm de same nigger, but yuther folks ain't de same.
speaker: Uncle Shade

utterance: Whose land is this?

Well, take your master's horse right round to the lot and brush him up a little. Colonel, come in ! It 's been a mighty long time since you 've darkened this door. Where Ve you been ?
speaker: Stith Ingram

utterance: I've just been out training my nigger dog. Old Shade started out before day, and just kept moving. He was in one of his tantrums, I reckon. But I 'm glad of it. It gives me a chance to take dinner with you.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Glad ! Well, you ain't half as glad as I am. That old Shade 's a caution. Maybe he was trying to get away, sure enough.
speaker: Stith Ingram

utterance: Oh, no, Shade knows well enough he couldn't get away from Jeff.
speaker: Colonel Elmore Rivers

utterance: Howdy, suh ! I 'low'd you wuz tryin' fer ter fin' yo' way ter de house, suh. Dat what make I come. De time wuz, suh, when my ole Marster wuz 'live, en long atter dat, dat no body on top er de groun' hatter ax de way ter dat house up yander. But dey 's been a mighty churnin' up sence dem days, suh, en in de churnin' de whey done got de notion dat it 's more wholesomer dan de butter en I speck it is, suh, ter dem what like whey.
speaker: Uncle Primus

utterance: Wait, suh ! des wait ! I ain't gwine ter be outdone dataway. Ain't you de same little boy what show'd me whar de buzzud nes' wuz on de two-mile place, en' which he use ter go 'possum-huntin' long wid me ?
speaker: Uncle Primus

utterance: Ah-yi ! Primus gittin' ol', suh, but he ain't gwine ter be outdone when it come ter knowin' dem what he use ter know, an* mo' speshually when he know'd 'em en durin' er de farmin' days. You er kind er fleshened up, suh, en you look like you er mo' settled dan what you wuz in dem days. Kaze I dunner how come you 'scaped breakin' yo' neck when you wuz stayin' at de Terrell plan tation.
speaker: Uncle Primus

utterance: Well, suh, I come mighty nigh gwine off wid my young marster. I 'speck I 'd 'a' gone ef he 'd 'a' had any chil lun, but he ain't had a blessed one. En it look like ter me, suh, dat ef de Lord gwine ter stan' by a man, He gwine ter gi' 'im chil lun. But dat ain't all, suh. I done been out dar ter Massy sip wid my young marster, en dat one time wuz too much fer me. Fust dar wuz de rippit on de steamboat, en den dar wuz de burnin' er de boat, en den come de swamps, en de canebrakes ; en I tell you right now, suh, I dunner which wuz de wuss de rippit on de boat, er de fier, er de swamps, er de canebrakes. Dat ain't no country like our'n, suh. Dey 's nuff water in de State er Massy sip fer ter float Noah's ark. Hit 's in de ve'y Ian' what dey plant der cotton in, suh. De groun' is mushy. En black ! You may n't b'lieve me, suh, but dey wuz times when I wuz out dar, dat I 'd 'a' paid a sev'mpunce fer ter git a whiff er dish yer red dus' up my nose. When you come to farmin', suh, gi' me de red Ian' er de gray. Hit may not make ez much cotton in one season, but it las's longer, en hit 's lots mo' wholesome.
speaker: Uncle Primus

utterance:
You ain't know much about my young marster, suh ; you wuz too little ; but he had de fam'ly failin', ef you kin call it dat. He wuz up fer whatsomever wuz gwine on, let it be a fight, er let it be a frolic. 'T wuz aU de same ter him, suh ; yit, ef he had de choosin', 't would 'a' bin a fight mighty nigh all de time. I dunner but what he wuz wuss at dat dan ole marster wuz, en de Lord knows he wuz bad 'nuff.
  Well, suh, nothin 'd do my young marster but he mus' travel, but stidder travelin' up dar in Boston, en Phillimindelphy, whar folks live at, he tuck de notion dat he mus' go out dar in de neighborhoods er Massysip. En I had ter go 'long wid 'im. I kinder hung back, kaze I done hearn tell 'bout de gwines on dey had out dar ; but de mo' I hung back, de mo' my young marster want me ter go. I wuz lots younger den dan what I is now, en lots mo' soopler, en I 'low ter myself dat ef anybody kin stan' fer ter go out dar spectin' ter come back wid breff in um, dat somebody wuz Primus. 'T wuz like de ol' sayin,' suh start out wid a weak heart ef you want ter come home wid a whole hide. En so we start off. My young marster wuz mighty gayly. He cracked jokes, en went on mighty nigh de whole time ; en I 'spicioned den dat dey wuz gwine ter be some devilment cut up 'fo' we got back. En sho nuff dey wuz.
  Well, suh, stidder gwine right straight to'rds Massysip, we tuck de stage en went ter Nashville, en den ter Kaintucky, en den fum dar up ter St. Louis. Hit look like dat whar somever dey wuz a hoss-race, er a chicken fight, er a game er farrer gwine on, right dar we wuz, en dar we staid twel de light wuz out, ez you may say. En when dey 'd move, we 'd move. Ef it had n't 'a' been fer me, suh, my young marster would 'a' teetotally ruint hisse'f wid gamblin' en gwine on. I seed dat sump'n had ter be done, en dat mighty quick, so I tuck 'im off one side en ax 'im ef he 'd bet on de hoss what I 'd pick out fer 'im de next day. 'Dat wuz des fun fer my young marster, suh. He tuck me right up, en des vowed he 'd put his las' dollar on 'im.
  'T wa'n't no mo' trouble ter me, suh, ter pick out de winnin' hoss dan 'twuz ter wash my face. Dat night I made my young mars ter gi' me a tickler full er dram, en den I went 'mong de stables whar dey kep' de race hosses, en 't w'an't no time 'f o' I know'd eve'y hoss dat wuz gwine ter win de nex' day, en de day arter, en de day arter dat kaze de nigger boys, what rode de bosses, know'd, en dey tol' me what dey would n't dast ter tell no white man dat ever wuz born'd.
  Well, suh, we sorter belt back on de fust two races, but de nex' un wuz de big un, en my young marster plankt down all he had on de hoss I picked, en we walked 'way fum dar wid mighty nigh 'nuff money ter fill a bedtick. De biggest pile my young marster got, he won'd fum a great big man, wid white whiskers en blue eyes. He look mo' like a preacher dan any boss-race man I ever is see. De man wid de white whiskers en blue eyes counted out de bills slow, en all de time he wuz doin' it he look hard at me en my y

utterance: Come on, honey, I'll turn you loose in dar wid 'em.
speaker: Aunt Mirny

utterance: Nummine ! You 're all here now, an' dat 's doin' mighty well atter so long a time. I b'lieve dat ar aig-nog done flew'd ter der heads. I know mighty well it 's done flew'd ter mine, kaze how come I wanter cry one minute an' laugh de nex' ?
speaker: Aunt Mirny
